Hopkins Allows Physicians
Greater Education

The Johns Hopkins University
School of Medicine has received
a grant of $235,000 from the
Commonwealth Fund to develop
a coordinated program of postdoctoral medical education, Dr.
Thomas B. Turner, dean of the
Hopkins medical faculty, announced today.
Dr. Turner said that the
Commonwealth Fund, through
its president, Malcom P. Aldrich,
had expressed the hope that the
Johns Hopkins use of the grant
would "usher in a new era in
post-doctoral medical education
and that it may serve as a model
to other institutions in the country."

Whistlers' Mother: This painting, by an unknown artist,
depicts the housemother of a college sorority patiently
waiting for a dance to break up in the next room. Note
how the artist has captured the anguish and devotion of
this lonely woman as she frets over her young charges
(who were nicknamed "The Whistlers" because of the
way in which they obtained dates).

Early Rembrandt: That Rembrandt was
born a genius is conclusively proven by
this little-known masterpiece. This, his
first known painting, astounded critics
and made the name Billy Rembrandt famous throughout Europe. Believe it or
not, Rembrandt created this masterpiece when he was two years old!

The Venus de Milo: Sculptured in the second century B.C. on behalf of a
Greek pencil manufacturer, this great statue
has won fame through
the ages as the symbol of
beauty parlors, bowling
alleys, upholstery firms
and reducing pills. Today
it is used primarily as a
vivid warning to small
children who bite their
fingernails.

The Thinker: What is The Thinker think.'
ing? This has been as baffling to scholars
as the riddle of the sphinx and "Who's
on first?" But now it can be revealed
that this statue is actually a Roman
warrior who had been asked, "Remember how great cigarettes used to taste?"
When he failed to answer, "Luckies still
do." he was turned to stone./

Woman in Water: Here is the original
of a great "lost" masterpiece which
I was able to acquire for the ridiculously low price of $8,500. I mention
this only to show what great bargains
you can find in art if you know your
subject. I determined the authenticity
of this priceless original by proving
that the small stain, upper left, was
made by Renoir's favorite coffee.

AT LEFT:"MASTER OF ALL MASTERPIECES"!"Here, in my opinion,"
says Dr. Frood. "is the greatest work of art. Note the bold, clean
strokes in LUCKY STRIKE, conveying the wisdom and pride of the
manufacturer. Note the perfect circle, representing, of course, the
perfect product inside. And in the product itself we find a truly magnificent expression of quality, good taste, pleasure and contentment.
Surely, there is no work of art that, over the years, has brought more
aesthetic joy not only to all of us in the art world, but to millions of

people in all walks of life.",

(Continued from Page 1)
period of formal education and
a decline in the quality of students are contributing factors,"
Dr. Turner said. "Therefore, we
must find ways of shortening
and improving the educational
processes."
Dr. Turner said that the "experiment" in pre-doctoral education at Johns Hopkins is 'succeeding beyond expectations."
This is the accelerated medical
education program to which
students may be admitted after
completion of their sophomore
year of college.
"Now," he said, "a complementary step is to examine carefully the wide area of postdoctoral medical education in the
hope that acceleration and enhancement of quality might be
acheived."
The 424 individuals now engaged in post-doctoral work in
medicine at Johns Hopkins include 239 physicians who hold
appointments as house officers
(interns or residents) of the
Johns Hopkins Hospital. The
total of post-doctoral students
represents an increase of nearly
300 per cent in the past 20 years.
Dr. Turner said that the grant
from the Commonwealth Fund,
which is payable over a period
of five years, would be used to
enable the medical faculty to
plan and operate a continuing
program of post-doctoral education.

Storm Hits MU, Student Berates BIA
Cancels Classes, In Letter To DSRC
Slows Activity
"A self perpetuating clique of
athletes," was the term used to
describe the BIA in a letter by
Tom Renahan read to the DSRC
at their meeting this week.
The author of the letter, a
resident of Adams house, stated
that he had written the letter
to counter Mr. Marshall Turner's
attempt to "deceive the Council" in his statement on the
BIA last week. He went on to
state that the BIA was not, as
Mr. Turner had stated, "made
up of the best people for the
job."
As proof of this he offered the
fact that he himself had applied
for membership on the BIA and
had been repeatedly "snubbed."

Outside Contractors
At three Peach contacted outside contractors and obtained
heavy equipment to work on the
snow; the arrival of a snow plow
late Sunday evening kept the
roads open for awhile, and at
10 p.m., Sunday night, Dean
Shaffer and Peach had practically- decided to keep the University
Open on Monday.
At 4 a.m., however, Peach was
awakened by a phone call from
the outside contractor who said
it was impossible to keep up with
the progress of the snow fall; and
at 7 a.m., Dean Shaffer decided
to close the University.

severe and hampered much of
their efforts, but the road into

to be closed again each time by

"IT'S HERE IF YOU WANT TO WORK FOR IT"
Even before Ron Spetrino received his engineering degree from Case he had good job offers
from six companies.
He joined The Ohio Bell Telephone Company
—his reason: "I was convinced an engineer could
go further here—if he was willing to work for it."
As soon as Ron got his feet on the ground
in telephone engineering, he was tapped for a
tough as.signment. The job—to engineer switching equipment modifications needed to prepare
Cleveland for nationwide customer dialing of long
distance calls.
Ron wrapped it up in five months, and found
he had earned a shot at another tough assignment.
In this job Ron helped engineer a completely new
long distance switching center for Cleveland. This
switching.center connected Cleveland with the
nationwide customer dialing network. It was
about a year later that Ron put- the finishing

touches on the specs for this $1,600,000 project.
Today, as a Supervising Engineer, Ron heads
a staff of five engineers and is responsible for
telephone switching in much of the greater
Cleveland area.
He supervises the design and purchase of $3
million worth of equipment a year. And even
more important, he is charged with developing
the technical- and managerial skills of his staff.
Ron knows what he's talking about when he
says, "In this business you have to do more than
a good job. We expect a man to be a self-developer.
We expect him to take responsibility from his
first day on the job and think for himself. You
don't get ahead around here by just doing time."
If you want a job in which you're given every
chance to prove yourself, and real responsibility
right from the start—you'll want to see your Place.•
ment Office for further information.

"Our number one aim is to have in all
management jobs the most vital; intelligent, positive and imaginative men we
can possibly find."
FREDERICK R. KAPPEL,President
American Telephone & Telegraph Co.

Whitehead Hall Coordinates Campus
By ED MORSE
Since Hopkins is a huge matrix of functions, departments,
projects and generally puzzling
activity there are many students
on campus who have no idea
what happens outside of the
classroom. In fact, almost no
one knows even a small part of
what goes on here. The follow-

ing is a glimpse of the machinations of one lonely building on
the campus: Whitehead Hall.
Some three hundred persons,
including thirty part time students, perform the seven-day-aweek, 24-hour-a-day functions of
the Plant Manager's Office at
Homewood, according to Mr.
Wesley A. Taylor, plant manager.

Mr. Taylor coordinates the
operation and maintenance of
buildings, operation of the central power plant, maintenance
of grounds, the working of the
book store, post office, food service, the operation of central purchasing and a wide variety of
other functions through the
Whitehead Hall "bureaucracy."

pleasant season with aspersions directed at various of the

great pleasure in presenting a few gifts replete with

DECK THE HALLS
for Christmas will be upon us quicker than you can say Jack
Robinson. (Have you ever wondered, incidentally, about the
origin of this interesting phrase "Quicker than you can say
Jack Robinson"? Well sir, the original phrase was French—
"Plus vile que de dire Jacques Robespierre." Jack Robinson is,
as everyone knows,an anglicization of Jacques Robespierre who
was, as everyone knows, the famous figure from the French
Revolution who, as everyone knows, got murdered,in his bath
by Danton, Murat, Caligula, and Aaron Burr.
(The reason people started saying "Quicker than you can say
Jacques Robespierre (or Jack Robinson as he is called in Englishspeaking countries)" is quite an interesting little story- It seems
that Robespierre's wife, Georges Sand, got word of the plot to
murder her husband in his bath. All she had to do to save his
life was call his name and warn him. But, alas, quicker than
she could say Jacques RObespierre, she received a telegram from
her old friend Frederic Chopin who was down in Majorca setting
lyrics to his immortal "Warsaw. Concerto." Chopin said he
needed Georges Sand's -help desperately because he could not
find a rhyme for "Warsaw." Naturally, Georges Sand could not
refuse such an urgent request.
(Well sir, Georges Sand went traipsing off to Majorca, but
before she left she told her little daughter Walter that some bad
men were coming to murder daddy in his bath, and she instructed Walter to shout Robespierre's name when the bad men
arrived. But Walter, alas, had been sea-bathing that morning
on the Riviera, and she had come home loaded with sea shells
and salt water taffy, and when the bad men came to murder
Robespierre, Walter, alas, was chewing a big wad of salt water
taffy and could not get her mouth open in time to shout a
warning. Robespierre, alas, was murdered quicker than you
could shout Jacques Robespierre (or Jack Robinson as he is
called in the English-speaking countries).
(There is, I am pleased to report, one small note of cheer in
this grisly tale. When Georges Sand got to Majorca where
Chopin was setting lyrics to his immortal "Warsaw Concerto,"
she was happily able to help him find a rhyme for "Warsaw,"
as everyone knows who has heard those haunting lyrics:
In the fair town of Warsaw,
Which Napoleon's horse saw,
Singing cockles and mussels, alive alive o!)

Weinstein played a fast and aggressive game as he continually

Help From Saul!
However he didn't do it alone
as he got more than ample help

Hapless Teachers were kept

building.

Despite a 14 point performance by Phil Berger, as well as a
10 point effort by Joel Sandberg,
Mt. St. Joseph High school defeated the freshman basketball
team in its first game, F3-49.
Berger and Sandberg, who
garnered 19 of their combined
total of 24 in the first half, got
the freshmen off to a seemingly
comfortable 30-23 halftime lead.
In the third period of play however, the club's previously good
defense collapsed entirely before
the aggressive play of the victors. The score was tied about
three times, before the Jays went
behind for the last time, 38-36.
They never seriously threatened
after that.
Berger and Sandberg were
aided by the shooting of Mark
Weiss, who hit for nine, and
Homer Schwartz and John Heller, who found the range for 7
apiece. Ed Greenberg gathered
the remaining two.. Greenberg,
although not particularly effective from the floor, led the

team in rebounding by picking
an even 10 from the boards.
For a few minutes in the first
half, it seemed as if the baby
Blue Jays might take the game
on foul shots. They jumped off
to a 12-5 lead, with half of the
points coming from the free
throw line, and were constantly
in command until the half.
Coach Robert Scott, although
pleased with the way that the
boys played in the first half,
was extremely disappointed in
their performance in the last 16
minutes. The reason for this
is twofold. The boys seemed to
suffer from a bad case of overconfidence in the second half,
which resulted in their allowing
Mount St. Joseph's a lot of easy
lay-ups. The coach was not
pleased with this, nor with the
fact that defense, which had
been stressed so much in the
preceding two weeks of practice,
seemed to be the main weakness
in the second half, although the

There is a growth of legitimate student political
activity. There are also attempts to discredit it.
Was the students' demonstration against the
House Un-American Activities Committee in San
Francisco legitimate? Are the attempts to discredit
- it justifiable? Today there are films and publications representing the Committee's viewpoint, both
about the demonstrations in San Francisco and
about the question of the Committee's violation of
citizens' rights to freedom of speech, press, and
assembly. To date,few have listened to the reasons
for the demonstrations against the Committee, and
to the students' view of what happened.
A fair judgment requires hearing the students'
side as well as that of the Committee. The Committee continues, and with it the question of the
right and duty of public protest.
The students' side is presented on a record made
of excerpts from recordings of the House UnAmerican Activities Committee hearings and demonstrations in San Francisco. The Sounds of Protest is distributed by Slate; a university political
party concerned with the protection of civil liberties
and civil rights.

Unparalleled Standard
"The United States can lead
them. It has the power to act.
But an unparalleled standard of
achievement is imposed on us.
We are forced to bat 1.000. Our
achievements and our failures go
around the world in hours.
"We're not victims of history,
however." he emphasized; "we're
makers of history. What we do
and what we don't do will make
a difference in the shape of the
world in which our children shall
live."
Respect for Complexities
Rusk said he hoped the members of the conference would go
away more confused than when
they came—with a greater respect for th% complexities of
world problems.
He pointed out that the outgoing cable traffic from the
state department each day exceeds the combined total of the
A.P. and UP.; that each day 15
international organizations meet
at which the U.S. is represented,
that the U.S. is a member of
394 international organizations;
an American policy decision has
to be rendered in some international forum every 3 minutes
of the day.
Immensity of Job
He criticized any proposal to
create a super secretary of state,
and noted the immensity of such
a job because his decision-making power "could not be delegated."
The red tape involved in getting
an idea from a lower official in
the Pentagon up to the Secretary
reveals why there is such is high
mortality of ideas in our system
of government. He suggested a
new official of the State Department might be created merely
to handle "summit diplomacy,"
the worth of which he doubted.
excursions
protracted
Such
abroad often bring neglect of
our top officials' constitutional
responsibilities and prevent
them from doing the homework
necessary if they are adequately
to make correct decisions.
He expressed confidence, however, that history was on the
side of America, rather than on
Russia's. The desires of the
merging peoples of the world—
the preamble to the charter of
the United Nations—these are
what the people of the United
States are all about. The revolutions around the world are
part of our own revolution. To
make the peoples of the world
realize this we must make our
goals and aims clear to our people at home and the peoples
abroad.

Whistlers' Mother: This painting, by an unknown artist,
depicts the housemother of a college sorority patiently
waiting for a dance to break up in the next room. Note
how the artist has captured the anguish and devotion of
this lonely woman as she frets over her young charges
(who were nicknamed "The Whistlers" because of the
way in which they obtained dates).

Early Rembrandt: That Rembrandt was
born a genius is conclusively proven by
this little-known masterpiece. This, his
first known painting, astounded critics
and made the name Billy Rembrandt famous throughout Europe. Believe it or
not, Rembrandt created this masterpiece when he was two years old!

The Venus de Milo: Sculptured in the second century B.C. on behalf of a
Greek pencil manufacturer, this great statue
has won fame through
the ages as the symbol of
beauty parlors, bowling
alleys, upholstery firms
and reducing pills. Today
it is used primarily as a
vivid warning to small
children who bite their
fingernails.

ing? This has been as baffling to scholars

Woman in Water: Here is the original
of a great "lost" masterpiece which
I was able to acquire for the ridiculously low price of $8,500. I mention
this only to show what great bargains
you can find in art if you know your
subject. I determined the authenticity
of this priceless original by proving
that the small stain, upper left, was
made by Renoir's favorite coffee.

"IT'S HERE IF YOU WANT TO WORK FOR IT"
Even before Ron Spetrino received his engineering degree from Case he had good job offers
from six companies.
He joined The Ohio Bell Telephone Company
—his reason: "I was convinced an engineer could
go further here—if he was willing to work for it."
As soon as Ron got his feet on the ground
in telephone engineering, he was tapped for a
tough as.signment. The job—to engineer switching equipment modifications needed to prepare
Cleveland for nationwide customer dialing of long
distance calls.
Ron wrapped it up in five months, and found
he had earned a shot at another tough assignment.
In this job Ron helped engineer a completely new
long distance switching center for Cleveland. This
switching.center connected Cleveland with the
nationwide customer dialing network. It was
about a year later that Ron put- the finishing

touches on the specs for this $1,600,000 project.
Today, as a Supervising Engineer, Ron heads
a staff of five engineers and is responsible for
telephone switching in much of the greater
Cleveland area.
He supervises the design and purchase of $3
million worth of equipment a year. And even
more important, he is charged with developing
the technical- and managerial skills of his staff.
Ron knows what he's talking about when he
says, "In this business you have to do more than
a good job. We expect a man to be a self-developer.
We expect him to take responsibility from his
first day on the job and think for himself. You
don't get ahead around here by just doing time."
If you want a job in which you're given every
chance to prove yourself, and real responsibility
right from the start—you'll want to see your Place.•
ment Office for further information.

"Our number one aim is to have in all
management jobs the most vital; intelligent, positive and imaginative men we
can possibly find."
FREDERICK R. KAPPEL,President
American Telephone & Telegraph Co.

DECK THE HALLS
for Christmas will be upon us quicker than you can say Jack
Robinson. (Have you ever wondered, incidentally, about the
origin of this interesting phrase "Quicker than you can say
Jack Robinson"? Well sir, the original phrase was French—
"Plus vile que de dire Jacques Robespierre." Jack Robinson is,
as everyone knows,an anglicization of Jacques Robespierre who
was, as everyone knows, the famous figure from the French
Revolution who, as everyone knows, got murdered,in his bath
by Danton, Murat, Caligula, and Aaron Burr.
(The reason people started saying "Quicker than you can say
Jacques Robespierre (or Jack Robinson as he is called in Englishspeaking countries)" is quite an interesting little story- It seems
that Robespierre's wife, Georges Sand, got word of the plot to
murder her husband in his bath. All she had to do to save his
life was call his name and warn him. But, alas, quicker than
she could say Jacques RObespierre, she received a telegram from
her old friend Frederic Chopin who was down in Majorca setting
lyrics to his immortal "Warsaw. Concerto." Chopin said he
needed Georges Sand's -help desperately because he could not
find a rhyme for "Warsaw." Naturally, Georges Sand could not
refuse such an urgent request.
(Well sir, Georges Sand went traipsing off to Majorca, but
before she left she told her little daughter Walter that some bad
men were coming to murder daddy in his bath, and she instructed Walter to shout Robespierre's name when the bad men
arrived. But Walter, alas, had been sea-bathing that morning
on the Riviera, and she had come home loaded with sea shells
and salt water taffy, and when the bad men came to murder
Robespierre, Walter, alas, was chewing a big wad of salt water
taffy and could not get her mouth open in time to shout a
warning. Robespierre, alas, was murdered quicker than you
could shout Jacques Robespierre (or Jack Robinson as he is
called in the English-speaking countries).
(There is, I am pleased to report, one small note of cheer in
this grisly tale. When Georges Sand got to Majorca where
Chopin was setting lyrics to his immortal "Warsaw Concerto,"
she was happily able to help him find a rhyme for "Warsaw,"
as everyone knows who has heard those haunting lyrics:
In the fair town of Warsaw,
Which Napoleon's horse saw,
Singing cockles and mussels, alive alive o!)

satisfied with his team's earlier
performances tried to seek
respite in changing his starting
lineup. Sophomores Paul Krouner, Rick Saull and Dave Cummins got the nod as the varsitY
coach used this opportunity to
get a better look at these ball
players under game conditions.
Despite all his juggling Sachs
had the job done by veteran
Dave Weinstein who "played his
best game yet." Besides scoring
16 points, the teams high, the
senior guard gave the team the
leadership it has been lacking.
Weinstein played a fast and aggressive game as he continually
stole the ball and set up his
teammates for vital scores.
Help From Saul!
However he didn't do it alone
as he got more than ample help
from Rick Saul!. The 6'4" soph,
also hit for 16 markers as well
as capturing the same number
of rebounds.
From the opening tap the
Hapless Teachers were kept
under control by the Jays even
though the they forced Hopkins
to play their sloppy brand of
ball through most of the first
half.
Returning to floor behind 3015 Towson resorted both to a,
zone defense and a full court
press. This created quite a dilemma for Sachs. If he used his
tall /pen to crack the zone he
would sacrifice the ballhandling needed to keep from losing
the ball against the press..
Sachs gambled and sent the
Jays into an unorthodox counter
full court press; in the hope
being table to steal the ball and
shoot before their zone could
set up. The gamble paid off.
Biggest Problem
The biggest problem facing
Coach Sachs this season has
been a unique one for him. with
as great as depth as he has and
a few real consistent players he
can't find the most effective
starting five.
Then every thing bogged down
and the Jays degenerated to a
haphazard almost nonchalant
type of ball game, They didn't
hit their shots and no one was
under the boards as most of the
rebounds were conceded not lost.
The offense which depends on
catching the opposition off balance with quick passes was a
complete shambles as passes
were casually flipped to one
another almost setting it up for
a Ford steal. In general the Jays
lacked the hustle that they
needed to win while they graciously helped Haverford to a 4921 half time lead.
'Needless to say coach Sachs
was far from happy with this
performance which was well below par performance, and he
must have let the team know it
during the break for a fired UP
squad returned to the floor. The
bench for the first time this year
showed life while the five men
on the floor exhibited the hustle
of the finest team at the Homewood in the last few years.
The startled Fords found the
game being carried to them as
sophomore guard Paul Krouner
led a stirring full court press.

Blue Jay Fencers Berger Gets 14 Points
Host Pennsylvania
In Nome Opener In Losing Frosh Effort
In a non-league meet Decem.ber 10, Hopkins blademen defeated the Towson Fencing Club
17 to 10.
Sweeping the foil, sabre, and
ePee matches with respective
scores of 6 to 3, 6 to 3, and 5 to
4, Hopkins left Towson little
chance to win the match.
On the merits of their performances in the Towson meet, the
Most outstanding fencers at this
Point are Smith Vaughan in foil;
Tom Ahern, who fences epee
and placed sixth in the State
Unclassified Foil Tournament
last Friday night; Paul Smith,
who fences both epee and sabre;
and Tim Koehler fencing sabre.
On the Hopkins fencing calender for this week are two events;
the State Unclassified Epee
Tournament, Frida-y, December
16, at 7:30 P.M.; and the Pennsylvania meet, Saturday, December 17, at 2:00 P.M. in the ROTC
building.

End Half Season
With 51 Record

Despite a 14 point performance by Phil Berger, as well as a
10 point effort by Joel Sandberg,
Mt. St. Joseph High school defeated the freshman basketball
team in its first game, F3-49.
Berger and Sandberg, who
garnered 19 of their combined
total of 24 in the first half, got
the freshmen off to a seemingly
comfortable 30-23 halftime lead.
In the third period of play however, the club's previously good
defense collapsed entirely before
the aggressive play of the victors. The score was tied about
three times, before the Jays went
behind for the last time, 38-36.
They never seriously threatened
after that.
Berger and Sandberg were
aided by the shooting of Mark
Weiss, who hit for nine, and
Homer Schwartz and John Heller, who found the range for 7
apiece. Ed Greenberg gathered
the remaining two.. Greenberg,
although not particularly effective from the floor, led the

team in rebounding by picking
an even 10 from the boards.
For a few minutes in the first
half, it seemed as if the baby
Blue Jays might take the game
on foul shots. They jumped off
to a 12-5 lead, with half of the
points coming from the free
throw line, and were constantly
in command until the half.
Coach Robert Scott, although
pleased with the way that the
boys played in the first half,
was extremely disappointed in
their performance in the last 16
minutes. The reason for this
is twofold. The boys seemed to
suffer from a bad case of overconfidence in the second half,
which resulted in their allowing
Mount St. Joseph's a lot of easy
lay-ups. The coach was not
pleased with this, nor with the
fact that defense, which had
been stressed so much in the
preceding two weeks of practice,
seemed to be the main weakness
in the second half, although the

There is a growth of legitimate student political
activity. There are also attempts to discredit it.
Was the students' demonstration against the
House Un-American Activities Committee in San
Francisco legitimate? Are the attempts to discredit
- it justifiable? Today there are films and publications representing the Committee's viewpoint, both
about the demonstrations in San Francisco and
about the question of the Committee's violation of
citizens' rights to freedom of speech, press, and
assembly. To date,few have listened to the reasons
for the demonstrations against the Committee, and
to the students' view of what happened.
A fair judgment requires hearing the students'
side as well as that of the Committee. The Committee continues, and with it the question of the
right and duty of public protest.
The students' side is presented on a record made
of excerpts from recordings of the House UnAmerican Activities Committee hearings and demonstrations in San Francisco. The Sounds of Protest is distributed by Slate; a university political
party concerned with the protection of civil liberties
and civil rights.

Unparalleled Standard
"The United States can lead
them. It has the power to act.
But an unparalleled standard of
achievement is imposed on us.
We are forced to bat 1.000. Our
achievements and our failures go
around the world in hours.
"We're not victims of history,
however." he emphasized; "we're
makers of history. What we do
and what we don't do will make
a difference in the shape of the
world in which our children shall
live."
Respect for Complexities
Rusk said he hoped the members of the conference would go
away more confused than when
they came—with a greater respect for th% complexities of
world problems.
He pointed out that the outgoing cable traffic from the
state department each day exceeds the combined total of the
A.P. and UP.; that each day 15
international organizations meet
at which the U.S. is represented,
that the U.S. is a member of
394 international organizations;
an American policy decision has
to be rendered in some international forum every 3 minutes
of the day.
Immensity of Job
He criticized any proposal to
create a super secretary of state,
and noted the immensity of such
a job because his decision-making power "could not be delegated."
The red tape involved in getting
an idea from a lower official in
the Pentagon up to the Secretary
reveals why there is such is high
mortality of ideas in our system
of government. He suggested a
new official of the State Department might be created merely
to handle "summit diplomacy,"
the worth of which he doubted.
excursions
protracted
Such
abroad often bring neglect of
our top officials' constitutional
responsibilities and prevent
them from doing the homework
necessary if they are adequately
to make correct decisions.
He expressed confidence, however, that history was on the
side of America, rather than on
Russia's. The desires of the
merging peoples of the world—
the preamble to the charter of
the United Nations—these are
what the people of the United
States are all about. The revolutions around the world are
part of our own revolution. To
make the peoples of the world
realize this we must make our
goals and aims clear to our people at home and the peoples
abroad.
